boston.name: Boston Marathon
boston.description: The Boston Marathon is one of the World Marathon Majors and features a challenging point-to-point course from Hopkinton to Boston. Known for its qualifying standards and historic significance, the course includes the famous Heartbreak Hill between miles 20-21.
tips: Train on hills - Heartbreak Hill comes at mile 20
Negative split strategy recommended due to net downhill
Weather can be unpredictable in April
Qualifying time required for entry

paceStrategy.summary: Start conservative despite downhill opening. Save energy for Newton Hills (miles 16-21), then use the final downhill miles to close strong.

segments.advice: Resist the temptation to bank time. Run 10-15 sec/mile slower than goal pace.
Settle into goal pace. Stay relaxed through Framingham and Natick.
Maintain rhythm. Wellesley College crowds will energize you at mile 13.
Run by effort, not pace. Expect to slow 15-30 sec/mile. This is where races are lost.
Stay mentally strong. Shorten stride, maintain cadence. Don't surge at the top.
Let gravity help. Pick up pace gradually. Trust your training.

boston.fuelingNotes: Take an extra gel at mile 15-16 before Newton Hills. The climbs increase energy demand significantly. Consider salt tabs if racing in warmer conditions.

faq.question: How hilly is the Boston Marathon?
faq.answer: Boston has 156m (512ft) of elevation gain, with the famous Newton Hills from miles 16-21 including Heartbreak Hill. Despite being net downhill (140m drop), the late hills make it challenging.

faq.question: Is Boston Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Boston is harder than flat courses like Chicago or Berlin due to the Newton Hills coming when you're already fatigued. Most runners find it 2-5 minutes slower than their flat marathon potential.

faq.question: What is Heartbreak Hill?
faq.answer: Heartbreak Hill is the fourth and final hill in the Newton Hills section, located between miles 20-21. It rises about 27m (88ft) over 0.4 miles. The name comes from the 1936 race when Johnny Kelley's heart was 'broken' after being passed here.

faq.question: What pace should I run at Boston?
faq.answer: Start 10-15 seconds per mile slower than goal pace for the first 5 miles. The downhill start tempts fast early splits that you'll pay for on the Newton Hills.

nyc.name: New York City Marathon
nyc.description: The NYC Marathon takes runners through all five boroughs of New York City. Starting on Staten Island and finishing in Central Park, this course offers incredible crowd support and iconic city views throughout the 26.2-mile journey.
tips: Prepare for bridges - Verrazzano, Queensboro, Willis Ave, and Madison Ave
Crowd energy is amazing but can lead to going out too fast
Weather in November can vary greatly
Lottery system for entry - very competitive

paceStrategy.summary: Run by effort, not pace. The bridges will slow you down - don't fight them. The crowds in Brooklyn can pull you too fast. Save energy for the Queensboro Bridge and the final Central Park hills.

segments.advice: Uphill then downhill. Don't chase fast starters. Stay controlled.
Incredible crowds. Resist surging. Lock into goal pace rhythm.
Pulaski Bridge at mile 13 - small climb. Stay focused.
Long, quiet climb. No crowds. Mental challenge. Run your own race.
Crowds return on 1st Ave. Willis Ave Bridge at mile 20. Stay patient.
Rolling hills in the park. Final push. Trust your training.

nyc.fuelingNotes: Take a gel before the Queensboro Bridge (mile 14) - you'll need the energy for the quiet, mental miles on the bridge. The aid stations on the bridge are limited.

faq.question: How hard is the NYC Marathon course?
faq.answer: NYC has 234m (768ft) of elevation gain - more than Boston. The five bridges create challenging climbs, especially the long Queensboro Bridge at miles 15-16. It's not a PR course for most runners.

faq.question: Which bridge is hardest in NYC Marathon?
faq.answer: The Queensboro Bridge (miles 15-16) is the toughest mentally and physically. It's a long, gradual climb with no crowd support, and comes when you're already fatigued.

faq.question: What's the best pacing strategy for NYC?
faq.answer: Run by effort, not pace. Accept that bridges will slow you. Many runners go out too fast in Brooklyn due to crowd energy and pay for it later. Even effort is key.

faq.question: How are the crowds at NYC Marathon?
faq.answer: NYC has the best crowd support of any marathon - over 1 million spectators. The only quiet section is the Queensboro Bridge. Brooklyn and 1st Avenue are electric.

chicago.name: Chicago Marathon
chicago.description: Known as one of the fastest marathon courses in the world, the Chicago Marathon is a flat, fast loop through the city's diverse neighborhoods. The course offers incredible crowd support and showcases Chicago's architectural beauty.
tips: Perfect for a PR - extremely flat and fast course
Crowd support is exceptional throughout
October weather is usually ideal for running
Pace yourself early - it's easy to go out too fast

paceStrategy.summary: Chicago is built for even splits. The flat course and ideal October weather make it perfect for locking into goal pace from the start. Don't go out too fast - the lack of hills means no excuses.

segments.advice: Easy to go out fast. Stick to goal pace. The crowd energy in Lincoln Park is incredible.
Settle into rhythm. Boystown crowds at mile 8-9 are legendary.
Halfway point. Check in with your body. Maintain form.
This is where flat becomes mentally tough. Stay focused. Crowds thin slightly.
Dig deep. The dragons and drums in Chinatown will lift you.
Final push on Michigan Ave. Trust your training. PR awaits.

chicago.fuelingNotes: Standard fueling works well on this flat course. Take gels every 45-60 minutes. The predictable pace makes it easy to plan exact timing. Don't experiment on race day.

faq.question: Is Chicago Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Yes! Chicago is one of the fastest courses in the world with only 89m of elevation gain. The flat terrain, great weather, and crowd support make it ideal for personal bests.

faq.question: How flat is the Chicago Marathon?
faq.answer: Chicago has just 89m (292ft) of elevation gain - essentially pancake flat. The only 'hills' are highway overpasses that feel like speed bumps.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Chicago Marathon?
faq.answer: October in Chicago typically offers ideal marathon conditions: 7-15°C (45-60°F), low humidity. Occasionally it can be warm or windy off the lake.

faq.question: How does Chicago compare to other majors?
faq.answer: Chicago is the fastest of the World Marathon Majors due to its flat course. It's easier than Boston, NYC, and Tokyo. Similar to Berlin in terms of PR potential.

london.name: London Marathon
london.description: The London Marathon follows a scenic route through the capital, passing famous landmarks including Tower Bridge, Big Ben, and Buckingham Palace. Known for incredible charity fundraising and fancy dress runners.
tips: Iconic landmarks provide natural pacing markers
Crowd support is legendary, especially at Tower Bridge
Weather can be unpredictable in April
Ballot entry system - very competitive

paceStrategy.summary: London is relatively flat with a fast finish. The crowd support is exceptional throughout. Use the landmarks as mental checkpoints and stay patient through the quieter Docklands section.

segments.advice: Three start areas merge. Don't weave. Settle into pace.
Quieter section. Stay mentally engaged. Don't zone out.
Around the skyscrapers. Crowds pick up. Halfway approaching.
Mental challenge seeing faster runners coming back. Run your race.
Tower Bridge is iconic and loud. Use the energy. Big Ben ahead.
Buckingham Palace finish. Dig deep. Crowds are incredible.

london.fuelingNotes: Fuel well before mile 18 - the final stretch along the Embankment and The Mall is fast and you'll want full energy for the iconic finish. UK gels at aid stations may differ from US brands.

faq.question: Is the London Marathon flat?
faq.answer: London has 145m of elevation gain - relatively flat but not as flat as Chicago or Berlin. The course is gentle with no major hills, making it suitable for PRs.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in London Marathon?
faq.answer: You'll pass the Cutty Sark, Tower Bridge, the Tower of London, Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, and finish on The Mall in front of Buckingham Palace.

faq.question: How hard is it to get into London Marathon?
faq.answer: Very competitive. The ballot has over 500,000 applicants for about 50,000 spots. Charity places, Good for Age times, and Championship entries offer other routes in.

faq.question: What's the weather like for London Marathon?
faq.answer: April weather is unpredictable: typically 8-15°C (46-59°F) but can range from cold rain to unexpected warmth. Layer up for the start and prepare for anything.

berlin.name: Berlin Marathon
berlin.description: The Berlin Marathon is known as the fastest course in the world, where most world records have been set. The flat, fast route passes through the Brandenburg Gate and showcases the city's rich history.
tips: World's fastest course - perfect for PBs
September weather is usually ideal
Incredible organization and crowd support
Brandenburg Gate finish is iconic

paceStrategy.summary: Berlin is THE course for even splits and world records. Lock into goal pace from kilometer 1 and don't deviate. The flat terrain and September weather create perfect conditions.

segments.advice: Start near the Victory Column. Large field - don't weave. Lock into pace immediately.
Through former East Berlin. Consistent pace. Soak in the history.
Halfway point. Check your splits. You should be on exact pace.
The 'business district' of the race. No surprises. Execute the plan.
Final 10K. If you've run smart, you have energy to push.
Unter den Linden to the Gate. One of the greatest finishes in running. Enjoy it.

berlin.fuelingNotes: Perfect course for precise fueling. With virtually no elevation change, your energy expenditure is predictable. Stick to your practiced plan - this is not the race to experiment.

faq.question: Why is Berlin the fastest marathon?
faq.answer: Berlin has just 67m of elevation gain - the flattest World Major. Combined with ideal September weather (12-18°C), wide roads, and great organization, it has hosted more world records than any other course.

faq.question: How many world records have been set at Berlin?
faq.answer: Berlin has hosted 11 world records, including Eliud Kipchoge's 2:01:09 in 2022 and Tigist Assefa's women's record of 2:11:53 in 2023.

faq.question: What's the best strategy for Berlin Marathon?
faq.answer: Even pace from start to finish. The flat course rewards consistent running. Pick your goal pace, lock in, and execute. Don't go out fast hoping to 'bank time.'

faq.question: How does Berlin compare to Chicago for a PR?
faq.answer: Both are excellent PR courses. Berlin is slightly flatter (67m vs 89m gain) and has more world records. Chicago has better crowd support. Weather is similar in September/October.

tokyo.name: Tokyo Marathon
tokyo.description: The Tokyo Marathon showcases Japan's capital from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building to the Imperial Palace. Known for exceptional organization, enthusiastic crowds, and unique cultural experience.
tips: Impeccable organization and crowd support
March weather is generally favorable
Cultural experience unlike any other marathon
Lottery system with very low acceptance rate

paceStrategy.summary: Tokyo starts with more climbing and finishes flatter. The net uphill profile favors a conservative start. The polite, organized crowds provide steady support throughout.

segments.advice: Start conservative. The crowds are enthusiastic but polite. Find your rhythm.
Pass the Imperial Palace. Enjoy the scenery. Stay patient.
Shopping district. Crowds thick. Halfway point - assess how you feel.
Can be mentally challenging. You'll see elite runners returning. Stay focused.
Course flattens. If you ran smart, you can push now.
Finish near Tokyo Station. Soak in the accomplishment.

tokyo.fuelingNotes: Japanese aid stations are impeccable but may have unfamiliar products. Bring your own gels. Aid stations offer rice balls and miso soup later in the race - an acquired taste during a marathon!

faq.question: How hard is Tokyo Marathon to get into?
faq.answer: Extremely competitive. The lottery has over 300,000 applicants for about 38,000 spots - roughly 12% acceptance rate. Charity and tour packages offer guaranteed entry.

faq.question: Is Tokyo Marathon a fast course?
faq.answer: Tokyo has 198m of elevation gain - more than Chicago or Berlin but still runnable for PRs. The net uphill makes it slightly harder than the flattest majors.

faq.question: What makes Tokyo Marathon special?
faq.answer: The organization is legendary - everything runs like clockwork. Spectators bow and cheer politely. Aid stations offer unique Japanese snacks. It's a cultural experience beyond just a race.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Tokyo Marathon?
faq.answer: Early March typically offers 5-12°C (41-54°F) with low humidity. Occasionally cold rain. Generally good marathon weather but bring layers for the start.

sydney.name: Sydney Marathon
sydney.description: The Sydney Marathon offers stunning harbor views, crossing the iconic Harbour Bridge and passing the Opera House. Recently elevated to World Marathon Major status, featuring Australia's most scenic marathon course.
tips: Harbour Bridge crossing is a highlight and challenge
Spring weather in September is ideal
Stunning harbor views throughout the course
Recently became a World Marathon Major - growing prestige

paceStrategy.summary: Sydney front-loads its climbing with the Harbour Bridge in the first 10K. Start conservative, tackle the bridge patiently, then use the flatter back half to make up time.

segments.advice: Significant climb early. Don't fight it. Run by effort.
Iconic crossing. Enjoy the view. Control your descent.
Undulating terrain. Stay patient. Opera House views ahead.
Some hills remain. Halfway done with climbing. Maintain effort.
Flatter section. Time to settle and push if feeling good.
Downhill finish to the Opera House. Let gravity help. Iconic end.

sydney.fuelingNotes: Front-load your fueling given the early climbs. Take your first gel earlier than usual (mile 4-5) before the Harbour Bridge effort depletes your stores. The net downhill finish means less fuel needed late.

faq.question: Is Sydney Marathon a World Major?
faq.answer: Yes! Sydney became the 7th World Marathon Major in 2025, joining Boston, NYC, Chicago, London, Berlin, and Tokyo. It's the first major in the Southern Hemisphere.

faq.question: How hilly is Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: Sydney has 234m of elevation gain - the hilliest World Major. The Harbour Bridge crossing in the first 10K is the main challenge. The course is net downhill overall.

faq.question: When is the best time to run Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: The race is in August/September, which is early spring in Australia. Temperatures are typically 10-18°C (50-64°F) - ideal marathon weather.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: You cross the iconic Harbour Bridge, run past the Sydney Opera House, through the Royal Botanic Gardens, Centennial Park, and finish with harbor views.

la.name: LA Marathon
la.description: The LA Marathon's 'Stadium to the Sea' course runs from Dodger Stadium through Hollywood, Beverly Hills, and Santa Monica, finishing at the Pacific Ocean. A point-to-point course showcasing iconic LA landmarks.
tips: Net downhill course but don't underestimate the climbs
Early morning start helps avoid heat
Hollywood and Sunset Boulevard sections are highlight
Finish on Ocean Avenue with Pacific views

paceStrategy.summary: Despite being net downhill, LA has significant climbing early. The heat can build as the morning progresses. Start conservative and take advantage of the downhill finish.

segments.advice: Tempting to fly. Resist. Save your quads for later hills.
Main climbing section. Run by effort. Enjoy the Hollywood sign views.
Rodeo Drive section. Some rollers. Maintain rhythm.
Course flattens and descends. Time to settle into pace.
Can feel the ocean breeze. Crowds build. Push if feeling good.
Downhill to the sea. Pacific Ocean finish is iconic. Enjoy it.

la.fuelingNotes: The early climbs demand extra fuel. Take your first gel by mile 5. The potential heat means prioritizing hydration - drink early and often. Carry salt tabs if racing in warm conditions.

faq.question: Is the LA Marathon a good PR course?
faq.answer: LA is net downhill (378m loss vs 282m gain) but the early climbs and potential heat make it challenging. It's possible to PR, but not as fast as Chicago or Berlin.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in LA Marathon?
faq.answer: Dodger Stadium start, Hollywood Boulevard, Sunset Strip, Beverly Hills, Rodeo Drive, Santa Monica, and finish at the Pacific Ocean.

faq.question: What's the weather like for LA Marathon?
faq.answer: March in LA can range from 10-25°C (50-77°F). Early morning is usually cool but temperatures can rise quickly. Prepare for potential heat.

faq.question: Why is it called Stadium to the Sea?
faq.answer: The course runs from Dodger Stadium in the hills above downtown LA to Santa Monica's Ocean Avenue, finishing with Pacific Ocean views.

marinecorps.name: Marine Corps Marathon
marinecorps.description: Known as 'The People's Marathon,' the Marine Corps Marathon passes iconic monuments including the Lincoln Memorial, Washington Monument, and finishes at the Iwo Jima Memorial. No prize money - just the honor of finishing.
tips: Marines cheer you on throughout - incredible support
No prize money - run for the honor and the medal
October weather is usually ideal for running
Hilly course with challenging bridges

paceStrategy.summary: MCM has rolling hills throughout, including challenging bridge crossings. The monuments provide mental markers. The 14th Street Bridge at mile 20 is notorious. Run by effort, not pace.

segments.advice: Start in Arlington. Some early rollers. Settle into rhythm.
Through Georgetown. Creek path is pleasant but has some climbs.
Past monuments - Lincoln, Washington. Flat and inspiring. Crowds great.
Out and back on peninsula. Can be windy and mentally tough.
The 'Beat the Bridge' section. Infamous climb. Marines cheering. Dig deep.
Final push through Crystal City to the iconic Iwo Jima finish.

marinecorps.fuelingNotes: Save an extra gel for before the 14th Street Bridge (mile 19). The bridge climb at mile 20 is where many runners hit the wall. The Marine support will carry you through.

faq.question: Why is it called The People's Marathon?
faq.answer: Marine Corps Marathon awards no prize money - everyone runs for the same reason: personal achievement. It's about the journey, not the prize.

faq.question: What's the 14th Street Bridge?
faq.answer: The bridge at mile 20-21 is the most challenging section. You must cross before the 'Beat the Bridge' cutoff time. Marines line the bridge cheering runners up.

faq.question: How hard is Marine Corps Marathon?
faq.answer: MCM has 198m of elevation gain with rolling hills throughout. It's not a PR course for most, but the experience and Marine support are unmatched.

faq.question: What monuments do you pass?
faq.answer: Lincoln Memorial, Washington Monument, Capitol Building, and finish at the iconic Iwo Jima Memorial. The course is a patriotic journey through American history.

bigsur.name: Big Sur Marathon
bigsur.description: Called 'The Ultimate Run,' Big Sur offers the most scenic marathon course in the world. Running along Highway 1 with Pacific Ocean cliffs, redwood forests, and the iconic Bixby Bridge. This is not a PR course - it's an experience.
tips: NOT a PR course - run for the experience
Hurricane Point at mile 12 is brutal but stunning
Bring layers - coastal fog is common
Grand piano on Bixby Bridge is a tradition

paceStrategy.summary: Big Sur has 610m of climbing - forget about pace. Hurricane Point at mile 12 gains 500 feet in 2 miles. Run by effort, walk the hills if needed, and soak in the views.

segments.advice: Gorgeous coastline. Don't start fast. You need every ounce of energy.
Beautiful but deceptive. The big climb is coming. Stay patient.
The monster climb. 500ft gain in 2 miles. Walk if needed. Breathe.
Recovery descent. Bixby Bridge ahead. Listen for the piano!
Iconic bridge crossing. Piano playing. Crowds cheering. Emotional moment.
Still hilly but manageable. Redwoods ahead. Finish in Carmel.

bigsur.fuelingNotes: Increase your fueling by 20-30% compared to flat courses. The climbing burns significantly more calories. Take gels at the base of Hurricane Point (mile 10-11) and at the top.

faq.question: Is Big Sur Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: No. With 610m of elevation gain including the brutal Hurricane Point, Big Sur is 15-30 minutes slower than your flat marathon potential. Run it for the experience.

faq.question: What is Hurricane Point?
faq.answer: Hurricane Point (miles 11-13) is a 2-mile climb gaining 500 feet. It's the most challenging section but offers stunning Pacific views. Many runners walk portions.

faq.question: Why is there a piano on the course?
faq.answer: A grand piano on Bixby Bridge has been a Big Sur tradition since 1989. A pianist plays for runners crossing the iconic bridge - one of the most emotional moments in marathoning.

faq.question: What makes Big Sur special?
faq.answer: Big Sur is consistently rated the most scenic marathon in the world. Dramatic Pacific cliffs, redwood forests, the Bixby Bridge, and stunning coastal views make it a bucket-list race.

paris.name: Paris Marathon
paris.description: The Paris Marathon runs past the city's iconic landmarks from Champs-Élysées to the Eiffel Tower, through the Bois de Vincennes and Bois de Boulogne. One of the world's largest marathons with over 50,000 finishers.
tips: Start on the Champs-Élysées - iconic setting
Two forest sections provide shade but can feel long
French crowds are enthusiastic with wine and cheese stations
Finish with Eiffel Tower views

paceStrategy.summary: Paris is relatively flat with some gentle rolling sections. The Bois de Vincennes and Bois de Boulogne sections can feel monotonous - stay mentally engaged. The landmarks keep motivation high.

segments.advice: Electric start on Champs-Élysées. Don't get caught up in the excitement. Settle in.
Large forest loop. Can feel long. Stay mentally present. Aid stations often have wine!
Beautiful river section. Notre-Dame views. Halfway point. Check your form.
Second forest section. Mental challenge. This is where the race is won or lost.
Leaving the park. Eiffel Tower coming into view. Crowds building.
Eiffel Tower backdrop for finish. Soak in the moment. C'est magnifique!

paris.fuelingNotes: French aid stations often include wine, cheese, and fruit - tempting but stick to your plan! Bring your own gels. The forest sections have fewer spectators, so mental fuel matters here.

faq.question: Is Paris Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Paris has 156m of elevation gain - faster than Boston or NYC but not as flat as Berlin or Chicago. With good weather and execution, PRs are possible.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: Champs-Élysées start, Bastille, Notre-Dame, the Seine riverbanks, Bois de Vincennes, Bois de Boulogne, and finish near the Eiffel Tower.

faq.question: Do they really serve wine during Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: Yes! French aid stations often include wine, cheese, chocolate, and fruit alongside traditional sports nutrition. It's part of the cultural experience.

faq.question: How big is the Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: Paris is one of the world's largest marathons with 50,000+ finishers annually. The massive field can cause congestion in the early miles.

amsterdam.name: Amsterdam Marathon
amsterdam.description: Amsterdam Marathon is one of the flattest courses in the world, starting and finishing at Olympic Stadium. The course runs through historic streets, along canals, and through the Vondelpark. A fast course with a rich history.
tips: One of the flattest courses in the world - PR territory
October weather is usually ideal
Historic Olympic Stadium start/finish
Canal-side running is scenic and flat

paceStrategy.summary: Amsterdam is pancake flat - perfect for even splits. The only 'hills' are canal bridges that are barely noticeable. Lock into your goal pace and execute. The course rewards consistent running.

segments.advice: Start in iconic 1928 Olympic Stadium. Perfect setting. Find your rhythm immediately.
Along the famous canals. Flat as a pancake. Lock into pace.
Alongside the Amstel River. Out and back section begins. Mentally steady.
Heading back to city. Can be windy along river. Stay focused.
City's famous park. Crowds building. Final push approaching.
Enter the stadium for the finish. Track finish like the 1928 Olympics. Glorious.

amsterdam.fuelingNotes: Flat courses make fueling easy - your effort is predictable. Standard protocol works well here. Take gels every 5 miles. The only variable is potential wind along the Amstel River.

faq.question: How flat is Amsterdam Marathon?
faq.answer: Amsterdam has just 32m of elevation gain - virtually flat. The only 'elevation' comes from canal bridge crossings. It's one of the best PR courses in Europe.

faq.question: Is Amsterdam Marathon good for a first marathon?
faq.answer: Excellent choice. The flat course, great organization, and reasonable field size make it ideal for first-timers. October weather is typically good.

faq.question: Where does Amsterdam Marathon start and finish?
faq.answer: Both start and finish are at the historic 1928 Olympic Stadium. You enter the stadium and finish on the track - very special experience.

faq.question: How does Amsterdam compare to Berlin?
faq.answer: Amsterdam is actually flatter (32m vs 67m gain) but has fewer world records due to smaller elite field. For age-groupers seeking PRs, both are excellent.

valencia.name: Valencia Marathon
valencia.description: Valencia has become one of the world's fastest marathons, nicknamed 'The Marathon of World Records.' The virtually flat course along the Mediterranean coast has produced numerous elite times and thousands of personal bests.
tips: One of the fastest courses in the world
December weather is ideal - cool and calm
City of Arts and Sciences finish is stunning
Excellent pacers throughout the race

paceStrategy.summary: Valencia is built for fast times. The flat course, December weather, and excellent pacers allow for aggressive pacing. If you're chasing a PR, this is the place to go for it.

segments.advice: Fast field. Excellent pacers. Lock into your group and trust the plan.
Near the Mediterranean. Usually calm winds. Consistent effort.
Through residential areas. Crowds enthusiastic. Stay with your pace group.
Heading back toward City of Arts and Sciences. You can start to see it.
Crowds building. The stunning architecture ahead. Dig deep for the finish.

segments.terrain: City of Arts and Sciences finish
segments.advice: One of the most beautiful finishes in world running. Trust your fitness. PR awaits.

valencia.fuelingNotes: Valencia's fast pace means higher carb needs. Consider taking gels slightly more frequently (every 4 miles instead of 5). The flat course and cool weather make absorption easier.

faq.question: Why is Valencia so fast?
faq.answer: Valencia has just 28m of elevation gain (virtually flat), ideal December weather (10-15°C), excellent organization, and fast pacers. It's produced numerous world records and thousands of PRs.

faq.question: Is Valencia Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Valencia is arguably the best PR course in the world right now. The flat terrain, perfect weather, and fast atmosphere have made it the marathon of choice for runners chasing times.

faq.question: What's the City of Arts and Sciences?
faq.answer: It's a stunning futuristic complex designed by architect Santiago Calatrava. The marathon finish weaves through this architectural marvel - one of the most photogenic finishes in running.

faq.question: When should I run Valencia for best weather?
faq.answer: The main marathon in early December offers ideal conditions: 10-15°C (50-59°F), low humidity, and usually calm winds. It's peak PR weather.

philadelphia.name: Philadelphia Marathon
philadelphia.description: The Philadelphia Marathon showcases American history, passing Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell area, and the famous Rocky Steps. The course loops through diverse neighborhoods and finishes at the Art Museum.
tips: Run the famous Rocky Steps at the Art Museum
Historic course past Independence Hall
November weather can be variable
Strong local crowd support

paceStrategy.summary: Philadelphia has moderate elevation change with some rolling sections. The Manayunk Hill around mile 20 is the key challenge. Run conservatively early to have energy for the final hills.

segments.advice: Start near the Art Museum. Historic downtown. Easy to go out too fast with crowds.
Beautiful park running. Some gentle rollers. Enjoy the scenery.
University area. Good crowd support. Stay consistent.
Heading toward the hill. Save energy. The climb is coming.
The 'wall' of Philly. Steady effort up. Don't blow up here.
Downhill return. Rocky Steps finish. Dig deep for the iconic end.

philadelphia.fuelingNotes: Save an extra gel for mile 18-19 before Manayunk Hill. The late climb requires reserves. The descent back to the finish allows for recovery fueling.

faq.question: What is Manayunk Hill?
faq.answer: Manayunk Hill (miles 20-22) is the challenging section of Philly. It's a steady climb through the historic Manayunk neighborhood. Expect to slow down here.

faq.question: Do you run up the Rocky Steps?
faq.answer: You finish near the Art Museum where the famous Rocky Steps are located. Many runners celebrate by running up the steps after crossing the finish line.

faq.question: Is Philadelphia Marathon a good PR course?
faq.answer: Philly has 178m of elevation gain - moderate difficulty. PRs are possible but it's not as fast as Chicago or Berlin. The Manayunk Hill is the main challenge.

faq.question: What historic sites do you pass?
faq.answer: The course passes near Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell area, and other historic Philadelphia landmarks. The city's revolutionary history is on display.

houston.name: Houston Marathon
houston.description: The Chevron Houston Marathon is one of the flattest and fastest courses in America. January timing offers ideal racing weather. The course loops through diverse Houston neighborhoods before finishing in downtown.
tips: One of the flattest courses in America
January weather is usually ideal for PRs
Excellent organization with chip timing
Strong qualifier race for Boston

paceStrategy.summary: Houston is pancake flat - perfect for even pacing from start to finish. January weather is usually cool and calm. This is a race where you can execute your goal pace with precision.

segments.advice: Start in downtown Houston. Flat from the gun. Lock into goal pace immediately.
Through historic Heights. Flat terrain. Great local support.
Around the park. Some tree cover. Stay consistent.
University district. Flat and fast. You should feel strong here.
Heading back to finish. Crowds building. Execute the plan.
Finish in downtown. If you've run smart, you have a PR. Trust it.

houston.fuelingNotes: Flat courses make fueling straightforward. Standard protocol works well. Take gels every 45-60 minutes. Houston's organization means well-stocked aid stations.

faq.question: Is Houston Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Absolutely. Houston has just 45m of elevation gain - one of the flattest courses in America. Combined with January weather, it's excellent for Boston qualifying and PRs.

faq.question: What's the weather like in January?
faq.answer: Houston in January typically offers 7-15°C (45-60°F) with low humidity. Occasionally it can be warmer or have cold fronts. Generally excellent marathon conditions.

faq.question: Is Houston a good Boston qualifier?
faq.answer: Yes. Houston is known as a premier BQ race. The flat course, good weather, and excellent pacers help many runners achieve their qualifying times.

faq.question: How does Houston compare to other fast courses?
faq.answer: Houston (45m gain) is comparable to Chicago (89m) and flatter than most. It's one of the best PR opportunities in North America.

twincities.name: Twin Cities Marathon
twincities.description: Called 'The Most Beautiful Urban Marathon in America,' Twin Cities runs between Minneapolis and St. Paul along scenic parkways and around lakes. The net downhill course offers PR potential with gorgeous fall scenery.
tips: Net downhill course - good for PRs
Peak fall colors in October
Lakes and parkways throughout
Summit Avenue finish in St. Paul

paceStrategy.summary: Twin Cities is net downhill with early rollers. The first half has more climbing. Save energy early, enjoy the lake views, and take advantage of the downhill finish on Summit Avenue.

segments.advice: Downtown Minneapolis start. Some early rollers. Don't chase the downhills.
Around the chain of lakes. Stunning fall scenery. Enjoy but stay controlled.
Along Minnehaha Creek. Generally flat. Find your rhythm.
Mississippi River views. Course flattens. Time to settle.
Entering St. Paul. Net downhill begins. Crowds building.
Beautiful tree-lined boulevard. Downhill to Capitol. Stunning finish.

twincities.fuelingNotes: The rolling first half requires steady fueling. Don't skip gels even when you feel good on the downhills. The net descent helps late-race energy but early hills still demand fuel.

faq.question: Is Twin Cities Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Yes. Twin Cities is net downhill (167m up, 234m down) with ideal October weather and beautiful scenery. Many runners achieve PRs on this course.

faq.question: What makes Twin Cities the 'most beautiful urban marathon'?
faq.answer: The course runs around multiple lakes, along tree-lined parkways, past Mississippi River views, and finishes on historic Summit Avenue. Peak fall colors make it stunning.

faq.question: What's Summit Avenue?
faq.answer: Summit Avenue is a historic, tree-lined boulevard in St. Paul with Victorian mansions. The final miles run down this gorgeous street toward the Minnesota State Capitol.

faq.question: How's the weather for Twin Cities Marathon?
faq.answer: Early October in Minnesota typically offers 5-15°C (41-59°F) - excellent marathon weather. Fall colors are usually at peak. Occasionally it can be cold.

grandmas.name: Grandma's Marathon
grandmas.description: Grandma's Marathon is one of America's most popular marathons, running along the scenic North Shore of Lake Superior. The point-to-point, net-downhill course from Two Harbors to Duluth offers beautiful views and PR potential.
tips: Net downhill course - good for PRs
Stunning Lake Superior views throughout
June weather can vary - be prepared
Named after the Grandma's Restaurant sponsor

paceStrategy.summary: Grandma's is net downhill but has rollers in the first half. The final 10 miles along Lake Superior are faster. Start conservative and use the downhill finish to close strong.

segments.advice: Start in Two Harbors. Early rollers. Resist the temptation to go fast.
Along the highway. Lake glimpses. Some rolling terrain.
Course trends downward. Lake Superior views. Find your rhythm.
Beautiful lakeshore running. Crowds build. Time to settle.
Entering Duluth proper. Downhill trend continues. Push if feeling good.
Downtown Duluth finish. Crowds amazing. Enjoy the lakefront finish.

grandmas.fuelingNotes: The net downhill helps energy conservation but the early rollers still require fuel. The cooler Lake Superior air can make you forget to drink - stay on top of hydration.

faq.question: Why is it called Grandma's Marathon?
faq.answer: The marathon is named after its founding sponsor, Grandma's Saloon & Grill, a restaurant chain in the Duluth area. The name has become iconic in American running.

faq.question: Is Grandma's Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Yes. With 111m net elevation drop (187m up, 298m down) and the beautiful Lake Superior scenery for motivation, many runners achieve PRs at Grandma's.

faq.question: What's the weather like in June?
faq.answer: June in Duluth can range from 10-25°C (50-77°F). Lake Superior moderates temperatures but fog and wind are possible. Be prepared for variable conditions.

faq.question: How scenic is Grandma's Marathon?
faq.answer: Grandma's is one of the most scenic races in America. The North Shore of Lake Superior provides stunning views throughout, especially the final 10 miles along the shoreline.

disney.name: Walt Disney World Marathon
disney.description: The Walt Disney World Marathon runs through all four Disney theme parks: Magic Kingdom, Epcot, Hollywood Studios, and Animal Kingdom. Character photo ops, incredible theming, and a magical experience make this a bucket-list race.
tips: Run through all four Disney theme parks
Character photo ops throughout the course
Very early start (5:30 AM) to beat Florida heat
More about experience than speed

paceStrategy.summary: Disney is flat but not designed for PRs - it's designed for magic. The 5:30 AM start, character stops, and backstage sections make it a unique experience. Run for fun, not for time.

segments.advice: Pre-dawn start at Epcot. Find your corral. Enjoy the fireworks.
Through Cinderella Castle! Character photo ops. Don't worry about pace.
Less magical backstage miles. Stay positive. More parks ahead.
Safari theming. Characters. Midpoint of the magic.
Sports complex and movie theming. Crowds support you.
Back to Epcot. World Showcase. Medal and character meet awaits!

disney.fuelingNotes: The early start and Florida humidity (even in January) mean extra hydration focus. Disney aid stations are excellent and themed. Take your time at character stops - that's the point!

faq.question: Is Disney Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: No. Disney is designed for experience, not speed. Character photo ops, early start time, and backstage miles make it slower. Run Disney for the magic, not the PR.

faq.question: Which parks do you run through?
faq.answer: All four: Magic Kingdom (including through Cinderella Castle), Epcot, Hollywood Studios, and Animal Kingdom. Each park has unique theming and characters.

faq.question: Why does Disney Marathon start so early?
faq.answer: The 5:30 AM start helps beat Florida heat and allows runners to finish before the parks open to regular guests. You'll run in the dark for the first few miles.

faq.question: Are there character photo opportunities?
faq.answer: Yes! Characters are stationed throughout the course for photos. Lines can form. If you want photos, expect to add 20-60 minutes to your finish time.

portland.name: Portland Marathon
portland.description: The Portland Marathon showcases the City of Roses with a scenic course through diverse neighborhoods, along the Willamette River, and past downtown landmarks. Known for enthusiastic local support and beautiful fall conditions.
tips: October offers ideal Pacific Northwest running weather
Course runs through diverse Portland neighborhoods
Strong local running community support
Relatively flat with some gentle rollers

paceStrategy.summary: Portland is relatively flat with some gentle rolling sections. The October weather is usually ideal. Focus on even effort, enjoy the neighborhoods, and use the river sections to find rhythm.

segments.advice: Start in downtown Portland. Flat and fast. Don't go out too quickly.
Through charming neighborhoods. Some gentle rollers. Find your pace.
Along the Willamette River. Flat and scenic. Lock into rhythm.
Through diverse neighborhoods. Great local support. Maintain effort.
Back along the river. Course flattens. Crowds building.
Finish in downtown Portland. Strong local cheering. Enjoy it.

portland.fuelingNotes: Pacific Northwest weather can be cool and damp - dress in layers and don't forget to fuel even if you don't feel as thirsty as in warmer climates.

faq.question: Is Portland Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Portland has 156m of elevation gain - moderately flat. With good October weather and a supportive local community, PRs are definitely achievable.

faq.question: What's the weather like in October?
faq.answer: October in Portland typically offers 8-18°C (46-64°F) with possible light rain. The Pacific Northwest climate provides good marathon conditions.

faq.question: What neighborhoods does the course go through?
faq.answer: The course showcases Portland's diversity: downtown, Northwest Portland, industrial areas, East Portland neighborhoods, and scenic river sections.

faq.question: How's the crowd support at Portland Marathon?
faq.answer: Portland has a strong running community and enthusiastic local support. The diverse neighborhoods each bring their own energy and character.
